choices.C: FortiGate can be configured as an LDAP client and group filters can be configured on FortiGate.

questions.question_text: What is the limitation of using a URL list and application control on the same firewall policy, in NGFW policy-based mode?

choices.A: It limits the scanning of application traffic to the DNS protocol only.
choices.C: It limits the scanning of application traffic to the browser-based technology category only.
choices.B: It limits the scanning of application traffic to use parent signatures only.
choices.D: It limits the scanning of application traffic to the application category only.

choices.A: Create a new firewall policy with the new HTTP service and place it above the existing HTTP policy.
choices.D: Set the TTL value to never under config system-ttl.
choices.B: Set the session TTL on the HTTP policy to maximum.
choices.C: Create a new service object for HTTP service and set the session TTL to never.

questions.question_text:
An administrator has a requirement to keep an application session from timing out on port 80.
What two changes can the administrator make to resolve the issue without affecting any existing services running through FortiGate? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: It's A & C
It`s A and B because C and D not possible to create never the range is from 300 to 2674800

Selected Answer: AC
A, C are correct

A: never mentioned changing the TTL
C:
config firewall service custom
set session-ttl never
D: without affecting any existing services so not the answer 
config system session-ttl
set default never
If you do not want the session to ever expire, you can enter , instead of specifying the number of seconds.never
https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.0.0/cli-reference/476602/system-session-ttl
https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Technical-Tip-How-to-set-Session-TTL-Value-to-Never/ta-p/198289?externalID=FD48961

i think A is wrong because its never mentioned changing the ttl so creating new policy will do nothing 
maybe B and C is the correct answer

Selected Answer: AC
In Version 6.2, can set session-ttl 0 in HTTP service as well

Selected Answer: AB
A&B
It is possible to create TTL session under a FWL Policy but not possible to configure ttl session to never (absurde)

Selected Answer: AC
A & C
C : Because its possible to set session TTL to never : https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Technical-Tip-How-to-set-Session-TTL-Value-to-Never/ta-p/198289?externalID=FD48961
It's A & B

Agree on A & C
But there is no such possibility to configure session TTL to never. Range is from 300 to 2764800.
a & C are correct
